Graphical abstract The reverse water gas shift (RWGS) reaction can be potentially used to convert captured CO2 into renewable synthetic fuels via syngas generation. However, this conversion pathway has not been yet realized because of a number of technological challenges, including a lack of catalysts which possess satisfactory catalytic performance. In this paper, the RWGS reaction over a 0.5 wt% Ru-promoted 40 wt% Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst is studied. Due to the Ru addition, CO2 conversion was improved more than two-fold as compared to the baseline Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst. The catalyst stability was significantly improved as well. Although Ru is known for its high activity in methanation reactions, the 0.5 wt% Ru-Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst maintained complete selectivity to CO formation. In order to investigate this intriguing finding, the catalyst was studied by XRD, SEM-EDS, STEM-EDS, and TPR, revealing the possibility of the formation of Ru-Cu core-shell nanoparticles. Further investigation have shown that the Ru-support interaction is also a crucial factor affecting the catalyst selectivity. To extrapolate the experimentally measured data, a rate expression was derived and kinetic parameters were estimated. The resulting reaction rate expression was implemented to assess the catalyst performance under a wider range of operating conditions. Among alternative solutions are CO2 sequestration (followed by storage) and CO2 conversion into synthetic fuels and chemicals. Converting CO2 into useful chemicals is of particular interest as this approach allows for CO2 recycling and introducing of renewable energy into the chemical industry production chain [2–4]. There are several optional pathways to synthesize fuels and chemicals using CO2 as a carbon source, including photo- and electro-chemical reduction, biological conversion, and thermocatalytic hydrogenation [5]. The implementation of the photo- and electro-chemical CO2 reduction routes has a significant potential but is limited by the low CO2 solubility in water and transport limitations [5–7]. The cost of cultivating and maintaining biomass growth systems remains a prohibiting factor for the implementation of the large-scale biofuel production [5]. As an alternative to the abovementioned options, the thermocatalytic conversion of CO2 can be seen as a more viable option due to its technical feasibility, considering its similarity to some well-established industrial processes [5]. Options include dry reforming of methane, the Sabatier reaction, methanol synthesis, and reverse water gas shift (RWGS), Eq. (1): (1) C O 2 + H 2 ⇄ C O + H 2 O Δ H 298 ∘ = 41 kJ/mol If CO2 is reduced to CO via the RWGS reaction using excess H2 in the feed with product water being removed downstream by condensation, the produced syngas can (a mixture of CO and H2) be later utilized to produce methanol and hydrocarbons via the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis [8,9]. This option provides flexibility in the type of product and high efficiency for conversion of CO2 captured from various waste streams, i.e., flue gases [8]. The water gas shift (WGS) reaction, the reverse reaction in Eq. (1), is a large-scale industrial process used in ammonia synthesis (to produce hydrogen via methane stream reforming) [10]. The most commonly used catalyst for this reaction is Cu/ZnO/Al2O3. As such, this catalyst has been extensively studied. It is well known that, at low temperatures, Cu-based catalysts can catalyze both the forward and reverse water-gas shift reactions [11–13], with little to no methane (CH4) formed as a side product. Methane can be potentially produced by CO2 methanation (also known as the Sabatier reaction), Eq. (2), as well as by CO methanation, Eq. (3): (2) C O 2 + 4 H 2 ⇄ C H 4 + 2 H 2 O Δ H 298 ∘ = − 164.9 kJ/mol (3) C O + 3 H 2 ⇄ C H 4 + H 2 O Δ H 298 ∘ = − 206.1 kJ/mol The RWGS reaction plays an important role in the synthesis of methanol from CO2, thus Cu/ZnO-based formulations have been considered as promising catalysts for methanol synthesis by direct CO2 hydrogenation [14]. While commercial Cu-based catalysts show good conversion and selectivity in methanol synthesis, they are often prone to fast deactivation by sintering and coking [15]. Coking mechanisms include the Boudouard reaction, Eq. (4), and CO reduction (reverse gasification), Eq. (5),[16] (note that CO is a product in the RWGS reaction): (4) 2 C O ⇄ C + C O 2 Δ H 298 ∘ = − 173.3 kJ/mol (5) C O + H 2 ⇄ C + H 2 O Δ H 298 ∘ = − 131.3 kJ/mol In order to extend the lifetime of Cu/ZnO-based catalysts, a substantial amount of work on studying the effects of adding various metal oxides has been conducted. Al2O3, Ga2O3, ZrO2 and Cr2O3 have all been found to increase the activity of Cu/ZnO catalysts. Al2O3 and ZrO2 increased the catalytic activity by improving copper particle dispersion, while Ga2O3 and Cr2O3 have been found to increase the specific activity per unit of Cu surface area [17]. Improving the stability of Cu/ZnO catalysts has been also achieved by adsorbing small amounts of colloidal silica on the precipitate; the activity of the Cu/ZnO/ZrO2/Al2O3 catalyst containing 0.6 wt% silica in methanol synthesis was maintained for 500 h [17]. For the RWGS reaction, Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts with Cu:(Cu + Zn) ratios of 0.25 and 0.75 have been found to achieve 5% and 15% CO2 conversion respectively using H2:CO2 = 1 at 515 K and 1 bar [18]. Meanwhile, the Cu/ZnO catalyst without the alumina support achieved only up to 12% CO2 conversion under the same conditions with a Cu:(Cu + Zn) ratio of 0.7. These findings indicated the significant effect of the Cu/Zn ratio on the catalyst performance [18]. Effects of feed composition were also studied, suggesting that a H2/CO2 ratio higher than 3 is essential for the RWGS reaction and it was suggested that a phase transition of the Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst occurs at high H2/CO2 ratios, improving the catalyst activity [10]. Formate species were suggested as an important intermediate for CO formation in the RWGS reaction [11]. However, other studies claimed that surface formates are not the main reaction intermediates in the formation of CO suggesting carbonyls and carbonates instead [19]. Although a substantial number of materials have been studied for the RWGS reaction, including transition and noble metals, and transition metal carbides [8], RWGS catalysts that possess high catalytic activity while maintaining good stability are still to be identified. The Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst is an attractive option due to its low cost and virtually complete selectivity to CO production. However, the Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst activity is low and the stability of this catalyst at elevated temperatures, which are required to achieve high RWGS conversion, is poor. Herein, we attempt for the first time to improve the Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst activity and stability in the RWGS reaction by promoting the catalyst with the addition of a small amount of Ru (0.5 wt%). The Ru-promoted catalyst performance was investigated as a function of temperature and space velocity and compared against the Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 baseline. The Ru promotion results in more than two-fold increase in CO2 conversion under most conditions tested. Interestingly, the catalyst remains completely selective to the formation of CO upon the addition of Ru, although Ru is well known as a good methanation catalyst. Importantly, the catalyst stability at elevated temperature (700 °C), which is more realistic for practical applications, was significantly improved after the Ru addition extending the catalyst lifetime by a factor of 2. Through the gradual removal of different components, it was determined that the Ru-Cu interaction is crucial for CH4 formation suppression. A rate equation was developed with the kinetic parameters estimated to find the best fitting model. The developed model was extrapolated to assess the potential for syngas production over industrially-relevant operating conditions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The baseline Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst (denoted as Cu/ZnO) was synthesized using a co-precipitation method. The ratio of Cu, ZnO and Al2O3 was kept at 40:50:10 wt%. Required amounts of 1 M solutions of copper nitrate (Cu(NO3)2·6H2O, Sigma Aldrich), zinc nitrate (Zn(NO3)2·3H2O, Sigma Aldrich), and aluminum nitrate (Al(NO3)3·9H2O, Sigma Aldrich) were dropwise added to a 1 M solution of sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3, Alfa Aesar) under vigorous stirring at 60 °C. After 24 h of aging, the resulted precipitate was filtered, washed and dried overnight under air at 110 °C. The dried precipitate was calcined under a continuous flow of air at 350 °C for 4 h, pelletized (40 MPa), crushed, and sieved to 250–425 μm particles. The 0.5 wt% Ru-Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst (denoted as Ru-Cu/ZnO) was prepared by wet impregnation using ruthenium chloride (RuCl3×H2O, Alfa Aesar) as a source of Ru and the uncalcined precipitate prepared as described above (after overnight drying at 110 °C). For Ru impregnation, the uncalcined precipitate was added to an appropriate amount of ruthenium chloride dissolved in acetone. The resulted slurry was sonicated for 30 min in a 20 mL vial placed in an ultrasonic bath (CPX962118R, Fisher Scientific), dried at 60 °C in air and calcined in air for 4 h at 350 °C. After calcination, the powder was pelletized (40 MPa), crushed, and sieved to 250–425 μm particles. The Ru-ZnO/Al2O3 and Ru/Al2O3 catalysts (denoted as Ru-ZnO and Ru, respectively) were prepared by the same method as described above, but removing the Cu or Zn precursors, while keeping the Ru content at 0.5 wt% Ru. The ZnO:Al2O3 weight ratio in the ZnO/Al2O3 support was kept at 5:1. For comparison, one Ru/Al2O3 sample was prepared by the same impregnation procedure but using the calcined precipitate (under air flow at 350 °C for 4 h) with no additional calcination step after the Ru impregnation. All catalyst formulations are summarized in the table below. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) was used to verify chemical composition (Prodigy SPEC, Leeman Labs Inc.). Specific surface area (SSA) was measured by a surface area analyzer (Gemini VII 2390, Micromeritics Instrument Corporation) using nitrogen as adsorption gas. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of spent catalysts was conducted to determine the extent of coking (Q500, TA Instruments). Temperature ramp was set to 10°/min for T ≤ 150 °C and 2°/min for T = 150–800 °C and the air flow was set to 40 ml/min. The corresponding temperature programmed oxidation (TPO) was conducted using a mass spectrometer (MS) under identical conditions (HPR-20, Hiden Analytical) and an FTIR analyzer (MultiGas™ 2030, MKS Instruments) to measure O2, CO, and CO2 in the reactor outlet. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained using a powder XRD diffractometer (D8 Discover, Bruker). Transition electron microscope (TEM) micrographs were obtained using a Zeiss microscope (100 kV). Elemental mapping of the catalyst was obtained by scanning electron microscopy coupled to energy dispersive spectroscopy (SEM-EDS) using a Zeiss microscope (20 kV). Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) was performed using the catalyst characterization instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) (AMI-300Lite, Altamira Instruments), using a 10% H2/Ar mixture and 5°/min heating rate. 2.3 Catalytic performance evaluation The experimental setup for catalytic performance evaluation is shown in Fig. 1 . Two mass flow controllers were used to control CO2 and H2 feed to the reactor. The reactor was made from a 1/4″ stainless steel union tee (Swagelok) connected to a 1/4″ stainless steel tubing on both sides (Swagelok), with a type K type thermocouple (1/8″, Omega Engineering) placed in a direct contact with the catalytic bed. The catalyst (ca. 500 mg) was loaded through the remaining tee opening, which was consequently sealed with a stainless steel plug (Swagelok). The reactor was placed in a tube furnace (Lindberg/Blue M™ Mini-Mite™, Thermo Fisher Scientific) with the tee containing the catalyst placed in the middle of the furnace. The temperature was controlled with the furnace built-in temperature controller (UP150, Yokogawa) using the thermocouple installed within the reactor (in contact with the catalytic bed). A back-pressure regulator (S01094789B, Swagelok) was used to adjust the reactor pressure. Water was removed from the outlet stream using a mist trap (AFM40-N02-Z-A, SMC Corporation) installed before the back-pressure regulator, Fig. 1, and a silica gel column (5182–9411, Agilent Technologies); the original adsorbent was replaced with orange silica gel (Fisher Scientific). Concentrations of CO, CO2 and CH4 in the outlet stream were measured on a dry basis (after the removal of liquid water and water vapor) with the IR analyzer (IR-208, Infrared Industries) continuously monitored using an analog-to-digital converter (USB 6008, National Instruments) and LabVIEW (National Instruments). In each experiment, a fresh (as prepared) catalyst was first reduced at 250 °C under a flow of H2 (200 ml/min) for 1 h. Catalytic performance was evaluated in terms of CO2 conversion and selectivity to CO production over the range of temperatures (250–500 °C) and space velocities. Deviations did not exceed 5% in all experiments, i.e., the carbon balance was in the CB = 0.95–1.05 range. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance and stability evaluation Comparison between the catalytic activity of the Ru-promoted catalyst (0.5 wt% Ru-40 wt% Cu/ZnO/Al2O3, denoted as ″Ru-Cu/ZnO″ throughout the text) with the baseline 40 wt% Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 (denoted as ″Cu/ZnO″ throughout the text) is shown in Fig. 2 . Error bars show standard deviation between three measurements using different batches of the catalyst. The selectivity to CO production, Eq. (8), was complete (SCO = 1) in all measurements reported in Fig. 2. For temperatures higher than 400 °C, more than two-fold improvement of the CO2 conversion is observed as compared to the baseline catalyst, as shown in Fig. 2a. At 500 °C, the CO2 conversion reached 46%, whereas the corresponding equilibrium conversion is 55%. For the baseline Cu/ZnO catalyst, only 17% conversion was achieved at 500 °C. Therefore, the Ru promotion results in a substantial improvement of the catalyst activity. The intriguing observation was that the Ru-Cu/ZnO catalyst did not produce any CH4, although it is well known that Ru is an excellent methanation catalyst [20–22]. This finding is investigated in Section 3.3. As GHSV is increased (Fig. 2b), the CO2 conversion decreases, as expected, due to shorter contact times. Selectivity to CO production was complete (no CH4 formation) over the entire GHSV range for both catalysts. While for the baseline Cu/ZnO catalyst conversion drops below 10% for space velocities higher than 100,000 mL/(g h), the Ru-Cu/ZnO catalyst maintains conversions ranging 20–30% over the 100,000–200,000 mL/(g h) range. For GHSV > 50,000 mL/(g h), the CO2 conversion improvement of more than two-fold is achieved as compared to the baseline Cu/ZnO catalyst. Note that for the Ru-Cu/ZnO catalyst the CO2 conversion approaches 45% at GHSV = 20,000 mL/(g h) which corresponds to an industrially relevant residence time of approximately 150 ms (e.g., industrial reformers are typically operated at contact times of few seconds [23]). The effect of the feed H2/CO2 ratio is shown in Fig. 2c. Complete CO selectivity was obtained over the entire space velocity range for both catalysts. As expected, conversion increases for higher H2/CO2 feed ratios, with a CO2 conversion improvement more than two-fold for the Ru-Cu/ZnO catalyst as compared to the baseline. As can be seen from analyzing Fig. 2a, the CO2 conversion improvement increases in a highly nonlinear way as a function of temperature. The improvement dependence on GHSV and H2:CO2 is weaker, which may indicate that the addition of Ru affects the apparent activation energy of the catalyst. Recall that only 0.5 wt% Ru was added while the main active phase content was 40 wt% Cu, i.e., the Ru content was only 1.2 wt% of the total amount of the active phase. To investigate the effect of Ru loading, catalysts with 0.5, 1 and 2 wt% we prepared and their catalytic performance was evaluated in terms of conversion and selectivity as a function of temperature, Fig. 2d. Slightly lower CO2 conversion was achieved for the 1 wt% and 2 wt% Ru loadings with the selectivity to CO formation remaining complete except for some minor CH4 formation at 500 °C for the 2 wt% Ru loading. Because no conversion improvement was achieved for the 1, 2 wt% Ru loadings, only the 0.5 wt% Ru catalyst was further investigated. Also, low Ru loading is required for practical applications. Catalyst stability is an important aspect of catalytic performance often overlooked in laboratory studies. As the Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst is known to deactivate rapidly in methanol synthesis [24], its stability in the RWGS reaction could be also poor. Stability tests were conducted for the baseline Cu/ZnO catalyst as well as for the promoted Ru-Cu/ZnO catalyst, Fig. 3 . In all stability tests discussed below the catalysts maintained complete selectivity to CO formation with no CH4 formation observed. For the Cu/ZnO catalyst the stability was relatively good at 450 °C, achieving the CO2 conversion of 30% in the beginning of operation with a decline to approximately 20% over 70 h on stream, Fig. 3a. However, for practical applications significantly higher temperatures will be required to achieve reasonably high conversions. At 700 °C, the initial conversion was 70% for the Cu/ZnO catalyst, Fig. 3a. However, the catalyst bed was completely clogged after 25 h on stream at that temperature as it was evident from increasing the reactor outlet pressure followed by the feed flow stoppage, which corresponds to the sharp failure recorded in Fig. 3a. In order to investigate the reason for this failure, two additional stability tests were conducted at 700 °C and two different space velocities, as it is shown in Fig. 3b, where the CO2 conversion is plotted vs. number of moles of converted CO2 per gram of catalyst. Although the reactor clogging and failure happened faster for a higher space velocity (not shown), the clogging occurred after a similar amount of CO2 was converted for both space velocities, Fig. 3b. This observation indicates that the mechanism of catalyst failure is coking rather than sintering, as the rate of sintering (which is induced by temperature) should not be correlated with the amount of converted CO2. With the Ru promotion, reactor failure occurred after more than 50 h as compared to 25 h observed for the Cu/ZnO catalyst under identical conditions, Fig. 3c. For all stability tests performed at 700 °C, Fig. 3, the same catalyst failure pattern was observed: initial slow rate of deactivation followed by a relatively small conversion drop and fluctuations, which were associated with the catalyst bed resistance build up (pressure increase at the reactor outlet), with eventual abrupt failure when the outlet pressure was equal to the feed pressure causing the feed flow stoppage, i.e., pressured drop buildup in the catalytic bed. The observed catalyst bed failure pattern indicates the possibility of strong coking, which can eventually lead to the catalyst clogging by deposited carbon. To test this hypothesis, thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) combined with temperature programmed oxidation (TPO was performed on the spent Cu/ZnO catalyst obtained after the reactor failure shown in Fig. 3. TGA-TPO signals are shown in Fig. 4 . There is an initial weight drop of approximately 6% for T < 200 °C which is clearly associated with the water desorption from the sample, Fig. 3a. For T = 230–350 °C, the sample weight increases by ca. 2% and then decreases by similar amount over T = 350–650 °C. The weight loss is attributable to the deposited carbon oxidation as it is evident from the CO2 and CO signals detected by both MS (Fig. 4a) and FTIR (Fig. 4b, c). The consumption of O2 is also evident from the MS signal, Fig. 4a. It starts as a gradual decline at ca. 350 °C with a sharp peak at 590 °C clearly associated with the sharp peaks of CO2 and CO release and with a step-like ca. 0.5% weight loss. The weight increase can be associated with Cu oxidation as the catalyst is expected to be reduced to certain extent under the reaction conditions due to the presence of excess H2. A simple calculation based on stoichiometry shows that, if the catalyst was fully reduced to Cu with all metal accessible for oxidation, the Cu → CuO conversion will result in a 9% weight increase. The observed 3% weight gain may indicate that some of Cu was oxidized during the reaction and not all Cu was exposed to O2 during the TPO test. Although O2 consumption was not delectable, the weight increase at T = 230–350 °C was clearly observed in repeated TPO experiments for the spent catalyst, with no such increase detected for the fresh catalyst. Note that, while 0.08 mol of O2 is expected to be released per 1 g carbon oxidized, only 0.03 mol of O2 will be generated per 1 g of oxygen released. Therefore, detecting O2 consumption associated with carbon oxidation is easier to detect. From the analysis of Figs. 3 and 4, it can be concluded that the reason for reactor failures was accumulation of the deposited carbon followed by complete clogging of the catalyst. Although the addition of Ru improves the catalyst resistance against coking significantly, the same type of failure was observed for the Ru-promoted catalyst. On the other hand, no reactor clogging was observed over similar time on stream (70 h) at 450 °C, Fig. 3a. As no CH4 formation was observed, the source of carbon formation should be CO (Eqs. 4 and 5), which coincides with the fact that faster deactivation was observed at higher CO2 conversions (CO is a product in the RWGS reaction). Although practical application of the current catalyst formulation at 700 °C is questionable because of fast deactivation (Fig. 3), it should be emphasized that operating at that temperature is not necessarily required. It will be very challenging to achieve nearly complete CO2 conversion in the reverse water gas shift process in a single path, simply because the required extremely high temperatures will cause fast catalyst deactivation. It will be probably more practical to recycle the product stream after removal of water and CO2, which can be done by membrane separation for example. Then the process can be operated at moderately high temperatures. Note that no deactivation was observed at 450 °C, Fig. 3a. Further work is required in order to identify an optimal temperature in the 450–700 °C range, to avoid fast deactivation while providing considerable high conversion. This work is currently underway in our lab. 3.2 Catalyst characterization The fresh catalyst composition was verified using ICP-OES. Relative deviations from the targeted composition did not exceed 10%, i.e., the measured Cu content was 39–43 wt%, with the target value being 40 wt%. The Cu/ZnO and Ru-Cu/ZnO catalysts were characterized by XRD, SEM-EDS, and TEM in order to investigate the effect of Ru addition on the catalyst structure and morphology. XRD patterns of fresh and spent catalysts are shown in Fig. 5 . As expected, CuO and Cu peaks were identified in both catalysts, with Cu peaks being absent in fresh catalysts. A characteristic peak of CuO located at 2θ = 38.7° was clearly observed in both fresh catalysts with two weaker peaks found at higher angles (marked with filled circles). These weak peaks were still observable in spent catalysts ran at 450 °C. The two sharp peaks associated with reduced Cu (2θ = 43.4°, 50.5°) appear for the catalysts tested at 450 °C and 700 °C with a weaker peak at higher angles (marked with open circles). The ZnO phase is clearly recognizable in the fresh catalysts and catalysts ran at 450 °C catalysts. Note that the ZnO peak at 2θ = 34° is not clear in the fresh catalysts due to the overlap with the CuO peak located at similar angle. The RuO2 peak is recognizable in the fresh Ru-promoted catalyst but no shift in the ZnO and CuO peaks were observed upon incorporation of Ru, as it can be seen from comparing patterns obtained for spent catalysts ran at 450 °C. Another important observation is that the ZnO peaks were not observed in the Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst tested at 700 °C. Since it well-known that Zn is volatile at high temperatures under reducing conditions [25], this sample was analyzed by ICP-OES. The analysis showed that practically all Zn was evaporated from the catalyst resulting in the 77.3:0.7:22.0 ratio for Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 (as opposed to 40:50:10 in the fresh catalyst). It is interesting that Zn evaporation did not occur to a significant extent for the Ru-Cu/ZnO catalyst, as it is evident from the XRD patterns (Fig. 4b). ICP-OES analysis of the spent Ru-Cu/ZnO catalyst tested at 700 °C showed the 0.5:52.6:34.8:12.1 ratio for Ru-Cu/ZnO/Al2O3, confirming the XRD findings. Evaporation of Zn only occurred to a certain extent in this sample resulting in the ZnO weight fraction reduction from 50 wt% to 34.8 wt%. ICP-OES analysis of the Cu/ZnO and Ru-Cu/ZnO catalysts tested at 450 °C showed no significant deviation from the original, as prepared composition: 40.0:50.5:9.5 and 0.5:40.7:49.5:9.3 ratios were measured for Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 and Ru-Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 respectively. All reported ICP-OES values are averaged over three separately prepared and measured samples. Relative standard deviation was less than 5% for all samples measured, i.e., Ru content was 0.44-0.47 wt% and Zn content was 33.4–36.1 wt% for the Ru-Cu/ZnO catalyst tested at 700 °C. The fact that the addition of 0.5 wt% Ru hinders Zn evaporation significantly indicates the existence of strong interaction between the Ru phase and the rest of the catalyst. The micro-scale morphology of both Cu/ZnO and Ru-Cu/ZnO was quite similar, as it can be seen from Fig. 6 a (the scale bar is 10 μm). To analyze the dispersion of active phases in the Ru-Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst, SEM-EDS elemental mapping of the Ru-Cu/ZnO catalyst was performed, Fig. 6b and c. The mapping showed generally good dispersion of all elements, at least at the microstructural level obtainable with SEM-EDS, Fig. 6c (mapping obtained from other location in the same sample showed similar results). Importantly, Ru was well-dispersed throughout the sample. Another evidence of relatively good dispersion of Ru and other phases is shown in Fig. 7 (STEM-EDS, the scale bar is 300 nm). All these findings are in line with the results of the catalytic performance evaluation and XRD analysis indicating that Ru does not act as a separate active phase (with expected methanation activity) but interacts with the Cu phase and the support resulting in complete selectivity to CO. TEM images of the spent Cu/ZnO catalyst (tested at 450 °C) are shown in Fig. 8 a. Similar morphology with round-shaped Cu nanoparticles and particle size ranging from 2 to 9 nm was observed for the spent Ru-Cu/ZnO catalyst, Fig. 8a. This is a typical morphology for metal oxide-supported Cu catalysts [26], with metallic Cu nanoparticles appearing darker due to their higher electron density. For the given instrument resolution, it was not possible to identify Ru nanoparticles. Particle size distributions (PSDs) acquired from TEM images (a total of 5 TEM images were obtained for each catalyst) are show in Fig. 8b. For both catalysts, particle size follows a nearly normal distribution with the average Cu nanoparticle size of near 4 nm. Therefore, the addition of Ru did not affect the Cu phase dispersion (at least in spent catalysts). Active phase (Cu) dispersion was calculated from obtained PSDs using the following equation (accounting for polydispersity): (10) D = ∑ i d p , max N S , i N V , i V p , i f i ∑ i d p , max V p , i f i = ∑ i d p , max π d p , i 2 A M e 6 M W , M e N A ρ M e π d p , i 3 π d p , i 3 6 f i ∑ i d p , max π d p , i 3 6 f i For a nanoparticle diameter dp,i , with the corresponding fraction fi obtained from a PSD (Fig. 8b), NS,i is a number of surface atoms, NV,i is the total number of atoms, and Vp,i is the nanoparticle volume. AMe is the surface area occupied by a single active site, NA is the Avogadro number, ρMe and MW,Me are the gravimetric density and molecular weight of the active phase. Total 10 TEM images were analyzed counting total 319 particles. Turnover frequency (TOF) was calculated using normalized reaction rates measured under differential conditions (conversion less than 15%): (11) T O F = M W , M e D R m a x (11a) R max = 100 r max L M e (11b) r max ( X C O 2 < 0.15 ) = F C O 2 , f X C O 2 W c LMe is the active phase (Cu) percentage loading, FCO₂,f is CO2 feed rate, and Wc is the catalyst weight. Results are summarized in Table 2, showing also specific surface area. The Ru addition resulted in a substantial reduction of the specific surface area, but the Cu phase dispersion was not affected. Therefore, the increase of catalytic activity for the Ru-promoted catalyst was not related to higher specific surface area of the catalyst or better Cu dispersion. Surface area reduced by 45% after the impregnation. On the other hand, the TOF of the Ru-Cu/ZnO catalyst was almost 8 times higher than that for the Cu/ZnO catalyst, Table 1 . TOF values reported for other catalysts range from 0.0104 and 0.0998 s−1 reported for 1 wt% Pt/Al2O3 and 1 wt% Pt/TiO2 at 300 °C [8] and 0.428 s−1 for Mo2C at 300 °C [27]. In order to investigate the mechanism of the enhanced catalytic activity and complete selectivity to CO generation of the Ru-Cu/ZnO catalyst, fresh and spent catalysts were analyzed by temperature programmed reduction (TPR), Fig. 9 . A typical H2 consumption peak associated with the CuO → Cu transition appeared for the fresh Cu/ZnO catalyst. The measured H2 consumption for this peak (centered at 316 °C) was 7.9 mmol/gcat (mmol H2 consumed per total catalyst weight), which is equivalent to 62.6% CuO reduction (as calculated using the instrument software). For the fresh Ru-Cu/ZnO catalyst, another peak, centered at ˜ 380 °C and partially overlapping with the CuO → Cu peak, was observed. The total H2 consumption for this catalyst was significantly higher (8.8 mmol/gcat). While this additional peak is clearly attributed to the presence of the Ru phase, its location and magnitude are different from those observed for the fresh Ru/ZnO catalyst (Fig. 9). Therefore, the second peak observed for the Ru-Cu/ZnO catalyst cannot be attributed to a separate Ru phase but should be related to Ru interacting with Cu. The H2 consumption for the fresh Ru/ZnO catalyst (as a result of RuO2 → Ru transition) was 1.1 mmol/gcat, which is very high considering the low Ru loading (0.5 wt% Ru vs. 40 wt% Cu): only 7 times lower than that for Cu/ZnO. This high H2 consumption is not surprising as it is well known that platinum group metals disperse well and have much higher turnover frequencies than other transition metals [28]. The Ru/ZnO catalyst remained fully reduced under the reaction conditions (see spent catalysts in Fig. 9), which is also in line with the properties of the platinum group metal catalysts. With respect to the appearance of the second peak for the fresh Ru-Cu/ZnO catalyst, a possible explanation could be the formation of the Ru-Cu bimetallic phase [29]. This phase can result from the strong interactions at the interface between Ru and Cu nanoparticles, leading to the Cu atoms forming an adsorbed layer on the Ru kernel [29]. In such core-shell Ru-Cu nanoparticles the Cu ″shell″ will ″mask″ the Ru atoms ″turning off″ the typical methanation activity of the Ru phase. Therefore, the possible formation of the Ru-Cu core-shell nanoparticles could be an explanation for the complete selectivity towards CO generation of the 0.5 wt% Ru-Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst. From the TPR results it can be seen that the double peak disappears in the spent catalyst after the reaction test at 450 °C. This observation may indicate that the bi-metallic Ru-Cu nanoparticles remain completely reduced under the reaction conditions. The Cu phase, on the other hand, remains partially oxidized under the reaction conditions, as it is evident from the appearance of the two single H2 consumption peaks centered at 220 °C and 260 °C for the spent Cu/ZnO and Ru-Cu/ZnO catalysts (3.8 and 3.7 mmol/gcat, respectively). This observation is in line with the XRD results (Fig. 5) also showing the presence of the CuO phase in the spent catalysts. The TPR peak location shift to lower temperatures for the spent catalysts can be attributed to better CuO dispersion (smaller nanoparticles). 3.3 Selectivity to CO production As it was shown in Section 3.1, no CH4 production was detected when Ru was added to the Cu/ZnO catalyst, although it is well known that Ru is highly active in CO2 methanation [20–22]. The characterization results (Section 3.2) provided some insight regarding enhanced activity and stability, as well as a possible explanation for the origin of the complete selectivity to CO production of the 0.5 wt% Ru-Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst. In order to further investigate this finding, Cu and Zn were gradually removed from the catalyst formulation, while keeping same preparation procedure (as described in Section 2.1). Removal of Cu (denoted as Ru/ZnO in Fig. 10 ) resulted in a significant drop in catalytic activity but the selectivity to CO production remained complete, with no CH4 formation detected while scanning vs. temperature and GHSV, Fig. 10. The most interesting observation from this experiment is that the 0.5 wt% Ru/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst acts as a RWGS catalyst exclusively selective to CO formation. Only after removing ZnO, the Ru/Al2O3 catalyst (denoted as Ru in Fig. 10) produced both CO and CH4 with the CO selectivity dropping below 40% at 500 °C (Fig. 10a). The CO2 conversion of that catalyst actually increased to 63% at 500 °C due to CH4 formation. The CO2 conversion of the Ru/Al2O3 catalyst was much higher as compared to other formulations when scanned over the range of space velocities, Fig. 10b, with a nearly complete selectivity to CH4 formation at relatively low space velocities. Altogether, these findings indicate that the interaction between Ru and ZnO could be necessary for CH4 formation suppression. Catalytic performance of the Cu catalyst in the absence of Ru (keeping 40 wt% Cu) was analyzed as well, Fig. 10c,d. While the Cu/Al2O3 catalyst showed slightly higher conversions, removal of Al2O3 resulted in a very significant conversion improvement. However, using Cu/ZnO for RWGS would not be practical because of Zn evaporation at high temperatures (see Fig. 5 in Section 3.2). Selectivity to CO formation remained nearly 100% for both Cu/Al2O3 and Cu/ZnO. To investigate the importance of the Ru-Al2O3 interaction, an additional Ru-Al2O3 sample was prepared using a pre-calcined Al2O3 support for impregnation (see Section 2.1 for details). The comparison between two samples is shown in Fig. 11 . It can be clearly seen that the Al2O3 support pre-treatment had a very significant effect on both CO2 conversion and CO selectivity. Calcining the support prior to impregnation resulted in lower conversion but higher selectivity to CO formation, attaining near 95% CO selectivity at high temperatures and space velocities. This observation is important as it indicates that it is possible to control the Ru selectivity by modifying the support structure even using same support material (Al2O3). 3.4 Kinetic model and parameter estimation Having experimentally improved the catalytic performance of the Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst through the addition of Ru, it is now desired to determine a rate equation for the developed Ru- Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst. This rate equation can be then used to predict catalytic performance over a wide range of operating conditions and assess the potential practical uses. If it is assumed that the RWGS reaction over the Ru-Cu/ZnO catalyst follows a similar reaction mechanism as the one suggested by Xu and Froment [30], an intrinsic rate equation can be written using the Langmuir-Hinshelwood–Hougen-Watson (LHHW) approach. Assuming no CH4 formation (as it was observed indeed for the Ru-Cu/ZnO catalyst), a simple RWGS mechanism is suggested (L stands for an active site): (12a) C O 2 + L ⇄ C O 2 − L (12b) C O 2 − L + L ⇄ C O − L + O − L (12c) O − L + H 2 ⇄ H 2 O + L (12d) C O − L ⇄ C O + L Following the Langmuir-Hinshelwood formalism (all reactions, including the surface reaction, can be represented by elementary reversible reactions), and assuming that the rate limiting step is CO2 dissociation, the rate equation for the surface reaction can be written as: (13) r = k f C O 2 − L L − k b [ C O − L ] [ O − L ] The concentration of the adsorbed species can be expressed as a function of their partial pressures with the corresponding adsorption/desorption equilibrium constants. An overall balance written on the catalytically active sites gives the final rate equation: (14) R R W G S = k r P C O 2 − P H 2 O P C O K R W G S P H 2 1 D E N 2 (14a) D E N = 1 + K C O 2 P C O 2 + K C O P C O + K H 2 O P H 2 O P H 2 Reaction rate and adsorption constants are given by the following equations: (15) k r = k r e f exp E a R g 1 T r e f − 1 T (16) K i = K i , r e f exp Δ H i R g 1 T r e f − 1 T Parameter estimation was done using the minimization of the sum of weighted residual squares of the CO2 and CO concentrations by means of the Trust-Region Reflective Algorithm [31]. Experimental values were measured by the IR analyzer (Section 2.3). Simulated mole fractions were obtained by integrating a set of ordinary differential equations (fourth-order Runge-Kutta) representing time evolution of all species participating in the RWGS reaction, i.e., CO2, H2, CO, and H2O: (17) ε d c i d t = − ε Q g f ( c i − c i , f ) V r + ρ c a t ( 1 − ε ) α i R R W G S In Eq. (17), ci is molar concentration for species i, ε is void fraction, Qgf is volumetric flow rate, Vr is rector volume, ρcat is catalyst density, and αi is stoichiometric coefficient. Initial guesses for adsorption constants (Eq. 16) were adopted from Xu and Froment [30]. Initial guesses for the activation energy and the reference reaction rate constant (kref in Eq. 15) were obtained experimentally (Fig. 12 ). Since previous studies were unable to obtain any statistically significant values for KCO2 [30,32], this term was preemptively dropped from the denominator of the rate equation. An MSE-based model selection criterion was employed to determine which parameters should be estimated and which should be left at their initial guesses to obtain the best fitting non-linear multivariate model [31]. This analysis revealed that all six parameters are estimable from the available data. The associated parameter estimation results are shown in Table 3 , based on the data shown in Fig. 13 . The suggested rate expression (Eq. 14) with the estimated parameters listed in Table 3 was found to fit the experimental data well, predicting quite accurately the experimentally measured mole fractions of CO2 and CO over a variety of operating conditions, as it is shown in Fig. 13 (error bars show standard deviation between three separate data sets obtained with different catalyst batches). 3.5 Model predictions As mentioned earlier, producing syngas for Fischer-Tropsch or methanol synthesis via the RWGS reaction is seen as an attractive option for the thermocatalytic conversion of CO2. Using the parameter estimates obtained, the model represented by Eqs (14–17) can be now used to extrapolate to a variety of operating conditions to examine the Ru-Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst’s potential ability to produce syngas with the proper H2:CO ratios. An example map of the model prediction results is shown in Fig. 14 . As the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis typically requires H2:CO ratios of ca. 2:1, examining Fig. 14 shows that these ratio is achievable over almost the entire range of temperatures with CO2 conversion above 50% for T > 700 °C. Similar H2/CO ratio is required for methanol synthesis. Although the mole balance used for extrapolation (Eq. 17) is very simplified and assume isothermal operation, it does account for the dependence on residence time and, importantly, relies on the rate expression verified vs. experiments. Another concern is of course a poor catalyst stability at 700 °C. Nevertheless, despite abovementioned disadvantages, the approach we have applied provides a framework to aid further catalyst development targeted to industrial applications. 4 Conclusion The RWGS reaction over the 0.5 wt% Ru-promoted 40 wt% Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst was investigated and it was found that the Ru addition results in more than two-fold CO2 conversion enhancement while maintaining a complete selectivity to CO production. As Ru is known as an excellent methanation catalyst, this finding is intriguing and promising, as it can provide an avenue for controlling selectivity of catalytic reactions. A thorough investigation have revealed the possibility of the formation of Ru-Cu core-shell nanoparticles which are highly active and selective to CO formation. Furthermore, by gradually removing Cu and ZnO from the catalyst formulation, it was found that Cu is not necessary for CH4 formation suppression and that 0.5 wt% Ru/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst is still completely selective to CO formation, although at lower conversion rates. It was also found the Ru selectivity to catalyzing the RWGS and methanation reactions in the absence of ZnO support can be controlled by simple changes in preparation routine. The 0.5 wt% Ru/Al2O3 can be highly selective to either CO or CH4 formation depending on Al2O3 calcination procedure. These findings are of general importance as they can open new avenues for controlling the catalyst selectivity. The 0.5 wt% Ru-40 wt% Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst was tested for its catalytic performance over the range of operating conditions, varying temperature, feed H2/CO2 ratio, and space velocity, including space velocities as high as 100,000–500,000 mL/(g L) which correspond to residence times of less than 50 ms. Under all conditions tested the catalyst was exclusively selective to CO production, attaining CO2 conversions as high as 50% at 500 °C and GHSV = 10,000 mL/(g h). The catalyst stability was significantly improved by the addition of Ru. However, extensive coke formation was observed at 700 °C. To extrapolate the experimentally measured data, a rate equation was derived from elementary steps and kinetic parameters were estimated vs. experimental data. The resulting reaction rate expression was implemented to assess the catalytic performance over a wide range of industrially relevant operating conditions. The applied catalyst development framework is general and can be applied on virtually any heterogeneously-catalyzed reaction. Future work will include model improvement, as well as further investigation into the mechanism of the CO selectivity and catalyst deactivation. coredata.dc:description: The reverse water gas shift (RWGS) reaction can be potentially used to convert captured CO2 into renewable synthetic fuels via syngas generation. However, this conversion pathway has not been yet realized because of a number of technological challenges, including a lack of catalysts which possess satisfactory catalytic performance. In this paper, the RWGS reaction over a 0.5 wt% Ru-promoted 40 wt% Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst is studied. Due to the Ru addition, CO2 conversion was improved more than two-fold as compared to the baseline Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst. The catalyst stability was significantly improved as well. Although Ru is known for its high activity in methanation reactions, the 0.5 wt% Ru-Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst maintained complete selectivity to CO formation. In order to investigate this intriguing finding, the catalyst was studied by XRD, SEM-EDS, STEM-EDS, and TPR, revealing the possibility of the formation of Ru-Cu core-shell nanoparticles. Further investigation have shown that the Ru-support interaction is also a crucial factor affecting the catalyst selectivity. To extrapolate the experimentally measured data, a rate expression was derived and kinetic parameters were estimated. The resulting reaction rate expression was implemented to assess the catalyst performance under a wider range of operating conditions.
coredata.dc:title: Highly-selective CO2 conversion via reverse water gas shift reaction over the 0.5wt% Ru-promoted Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst
